When Do Networks Create Value?

Social Capital, Brokerage, and Business Performance

SMM638 Network Analytics

The Leading Question

Important

When do networks create value for individuals and organizations?

This question drives network theory‚Äôs investigation into how structural position translates into tangible outcomes.

A Theoretical Framework

Social Capital Social Homogeneity
Network Flow Capitalization (Value Creation) Contagion
Network Architecture Coordination Adaptation (Network Change)

Our focus today: How network position creates value through social capital mechanisms

Source: Scott (2011), SAGE Handbook of Social Network Analysis, p. 47

Two Theories of Network Value

üåâ Bridging Social Capital

Sparse networks bring value through access to diverse information and new opportunities.

Mechanism: Network Brokerage

Key scholar: Ron Burt

üîó Bonding Social Capital

Dense networks create value by fostering trust and enabling cooperation.

Mechanism: Network Closure

Key scholar: James Coleman

PART ONE

Bonding Social Capital

How dense networks create value through closure and trust

What is Network Closure?

Definition

Network closure is the tendency for a network to present direct ties between pairs of nodes, creating dense, interconnected structures.

Key insight: When your friends know each other, information travels in closed loops.

This creates an environment where:

  • Reputation effects can operate
  • Social norms can be enforced
  • Trust can be established and maintained
Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)

# Create a fully connected network
g <- make_full_graph(5)
V(g)$name <- LETTERS[1:5]

ggraph(g, layout = "circle") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray60", width = 1.2) +
  geom_node_point(size = 12, color = "#c9a227") +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), color = "white", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "High-Closure Network") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#722f37", face = "bold"))

How Closure Creates Value

üõ°Ô∏è Trust & Cooperation

Dense networks enable reciprocity. If A cheats B, mutual friend C will learn and sanction A.

üì¢ Reputation Effects

Bad behavior spreads quickly. Cheating becomes ‚Äúunbearable when mutual friends uncover the deceit.‚Äù

‚öñÔ∏è Norm Enforcement

Closed networks establish and enforce shared expectations, reducing uncertainty in transactions.

‚ÄúEmbedded ties protect the integrity of social and economic transactions.‚Äù ‚Äî Coleman‚Äôs view of social capital

Measuring Closure: Clustering Coefficient

For a node \(i\) with degree \(k_i\), the clustering coefficient is:

\[C_i = \frac{2L_i}{k_i(k_i - 1)}\]

where \(L_i\) = number of links between the \(k_i\) neighbors of node \(i\)


Interpretation: What proportion of my friends‚Äô possible friendships actually exist?

Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)
library(patchwork)

# Three examples of clustering
# C = 0
g1 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)
V(g1)$color <- c("#722f37", "#c9a227", "#c9a227", "#c9a227")

# C = 1/3
g2 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4, 2,3), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)
V(g2)$color <- c("#722f37", "#c9a227", "#c9a227", "#c9a227")

# C = 1
g3 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4, 2,3, 3,4, 2,4), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)
V(g3)$color <- c("#722f37", "#c9a227", "#c9a227", "#c9a227")

p1 <- ggraph(g1, layout = "star") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g1)$color)), size = 10) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "C = 0") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))

p2 <- ggraph(g2, layout = "star") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g2)$color)), size = 10) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "C = 1/3") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))

p3 <- ggraph(g3, layout = "star") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g3)$color)), size = 10) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "C = 1") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))

p1 + p2 + p3

Center node (burgundy) with three neighbors (gold)

PART TWO

Bridging Social Capital

How sparse networks create value through brokerage and information access

The Strength of Weak Ties

Granovetter‚Äôs Discovery (1973)

Job seekers found new positions through acquaintances rather than close friends‚Äîpeople they saw ‚Äúoccasionally‚Äù or ‚Äúrarely.‚Äù

Why? Your close friends know what you know.

  • Strong ties move in overlapping social circles
  • Information from friends is often redundant
  • Weak ties connect to different social worlds
  • Each acquaintance provides unique, non-overlapping information
Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)

# Create a network showing weak ties bridging communities
set.seed(42)
g <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(
  1,2, 1,3, 2,3,  # Left cluster (strong ties)
  1,4,            # Weak tie bridge
  4,5, 4,6, 5,6,  # Right cluster (strong ties)
  1,7,            # Another weak tie
  7,8, 7,9        # Another cluster
), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)

E(g)$type <- c("strong", "strong", "strong", "weak", "strong", "strong", "strong", "weak", "strong", "strong")
E(g)$width <- ifelse(E(g)$type == "strong", 2, 1)
E(g)$lty <- ifelse(E(g)$type == "strong", 1, 2)

V(g)$color <- c("#c9a227", rep("#1a5f3c", 8))
V(g)$size <- c(12, rep(8, 8))

ggraph(g, layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(aes(width = I(E(g)$width), linetype = I(E(g)$lty)), 
                 color = "gray50", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g)$color), size = I(V(g)$size))) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "Weak Ties Bridge Communities") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#1a5f3c", face = "bold"))

Dashed lines = weak ties spanning clusters

Source: Granovetter (1973), ‚ÄúThe Strength of Weak Ties,‚Äù American Journal of Sociology

Structural Holes: Burt‚Äôs Framework

Definition

A structural hole is the ‚Äúempty space‚Äù in a network between two sets of nodes that do not otherwise interact closely.

Individuals who span structural holes gain:

Information

Early access to diverse, non-redundant knowledge

Control

Ability to broker and synthesize across groups

Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)

# Create structural hole visualization
g <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(
  1,2, 1,3, 2,3, 2,4, 3,4,  # Left cluster
  5,6, 5,7, 6,7, 6,8, 7,8,  # Right cluster
  4,9, 8,9                   # Broker connections
), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)

V(g)$color <- c(rep("#722f37", 4), rep("#1a5f3c", 4), "#c9a227")
V(g)$size <- c(rep(8, 8), 14)
V(g)$label <- c(rep("", 8), "B")

coords <- matrix(c(
  -2, 1,   # 1
  -2, 0,   # 2
  -1.5, 0.5, # 3
  -1, 0,   # 4
  2, 1,    # 5
  2, 0,    # 6
  1.5, 0.5,  # 7
  1, 0,    # 8
  0, 0     # 9 (broker)
), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE)

ggraph(g, layout = coords) +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g)$color), size = I(V(g)$size))) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = V(g)$label), color = "#1a5f3c", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "Broker Spanning Structural Hole") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#1a5f3c", face = "bold"))

Node B spans the gap between two clusters

Source: Burt (1992), Structural Holes: The Social Structure of Competition

The Brokerage Advantage

1. Non-Redundant Information

Brokers access information from multiple, unconnected sources‚Äîeach providing unique knowledge.

2. Early Access

Information reaches brokers first because they sit at the intersection of communication flows.

3. Strategic Control

Brokers can regulate information flow, synthesize ideas across groups, and create new combinations.

üí° ‚ÄúPeople with networks rich in structural holes have better ideas.‚Äù ‚Äî Ron Burt, research on managers at a large electronics company

Source: Burt (2004), ‚ÄúStructural Holes and Good Ideas,‚Äù American Journal of Sociology

Measuring Brokerage Position

Betweenness Centrality

How often does a node lie on the shortest path between others?

\[C_B(i) = \sum_{j<k} \frac{g_{jk}(i)}{g_{jk}}\]

Identifies nodes that can interrupt flow between actors.

Burt‚Äôs Constraint Index

How much of your network is concentrated in redundant contacts?

  • Low constraint = many structural holes = brokerage advantage
  • High constraint = contacts all know each other = no brokerage
Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)
library(patchwork)

# High constraint (closed network)
g1 <- make_full_graph(4)
V(g1)$color <- c("#c9a227", rep("#999999", 3))

# Low constraint (structural holes)
g2 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4, 1,5), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)
V(g2)$color <- c("#c9a227", rep("#999999", 4))

p1 <- ggraph(g1, layout = "star") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g1)$color)), size = 10) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "High Constraint") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 12))

p2 <- ggraph(g2, layout = "star") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g2)$color)), size = 10) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "Low Constraint") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 12))

p1 + p2

Gold node = focal actor. Lower constraint = richer structural holes.

PART THREE

Business Applications

How organizations leverage network analytics for competitive advantage

Case: RBC Fraud Detection

CASE STUDY Royal Bank of Canada ‚Äî First-Party Fraud

The Challenge: Fraudsters build good credit over years, then ‚Äúbust out‚Äù by withdrawing from multiple seemingly unconnected accounts.

Network Insight

Fraudsters share connections: same phone numbers, addresses, or patterns of money transfers. Their connectivity is both their strength and vulnerability.

SNA Application:

  • Map money flow networks between accounts
  • Identify dense clusters sharing data elements
  • Use homophily‚Äîfraudsters connect to fraudsters
Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)

# Fraud ring visualization
set.seed(123)
# Fraud cluster
fraud <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(
  1,2, 1,3, 2,3, 2,4, 3,4, 1,4
), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)

# Legitimate accounts
legit <- graph(edges=c(), n=4, directed=FALSE)

# Combine
g <- fraud + legit
V(g)$color <- c(rep("#722f37", 4), rep("#1a5f3c", 4))
V(g)$type <- c(rep("Fraud Ring", 4), rep("Legitimate", 4))

coords <- matrix(c(
  -1.5, 0.5,
  -1, 1,
  -1, 0,
  -0.5, 0.5,
  1, 1,
  1.5, 0.8,
  1.2, 0.3,
  1.6, 0.1
), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE)

ggraph(g, layout = coords) +
  geom_edge_link(color = "#722f37", width = 1.5) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g)$color)), size = 10) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "Fraud Ring Detection") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#722f37", face = "bold"))

Result: Reduced false positive rate from 85:1 to target of 10:1

Source: RBC Social Network Analysis case (Ivey Publishing)

Networks Inside Organizations

Organizations have two structures: formal hierarchy (org charts) and informal networks (who actually works with whom).

ü§ù Collaboration

Identify top value creators and connect them with emerging talent. Combat ‚Äúgroupthink‚Äù in isolated teams.

üîÑ Change Agents

Find influential nodes who shape organizational culture. Use them to accelerate change initiatives.

üåâ Information Brokers

Locate people who bridge functions. Often invisible but crucial‚Äîlosing them disrupts knowledge flow.

‚ÄúNetwork analysis is a tool that allows leaders to optimize collaboration and information exchange, rather than maximizing structures and hoping for the best.‚Äù ‚Äî Cross & Thomas

Source: UVA Darden Technical Note on Network Analysis

Inter-Organizational Networks

Board Interlocks

When the same individual serves on multiple corporate boards, organizations become connected through a shared director network.

Strategic implications:

  • Information diffusion: Best practices spread through connected boards
  • Coordination: Linked firms may align strategies
  • Status transfer: Connections to prestigious boards signal legitimacy
  • Resource access: Networks facilitate M&A and partnerships
Code 
library(igraph)
library(ggraph)

# Board interlock network
g <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(
  "Boeing", "Dir1",
  "3M", "Dir1",
  "Sara Lee", "Dir1",
  "Xerox", "Dir2",
  "Dow", "Dir2",
  "Sara Lee", "Dir2"
), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE)

V(g)$type <- ifelse(grepl("Dir", V(g)$name), "Director", "Company")
V(g)$color <- ifelse(V(g)$type == "Director", "#c9a227", "#1a5f3c")
V(g)$size <- ifelse(V(g)$type == "Director", 8, 12)
V(g)$label <- ifelse(V(g)$type == "Director", "", V(g)$name)

ggraph(g, layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(color = "#c9a227", width = 1.5, alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g)$color), size = I(V(g)$size))) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = V(g)$label), repel = TRUE, size = 3) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "Board Interlock Network") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#1a5f3c", face = "bold"))

Directors (gold) create bridges between firms

Burt (2007): ‚ÄúThe small world of organizations and markets‚Äù

The Strategic Tension

Closure: Safety

  • Trust through mutual monitoring
  • Protection from cheating
  • Stable, predictable relationships
  • Good for high-risk transactions

Tradeoff: Redundant information, limited novelty

Brokerage: Opportunity

  • Access to diverse information
  • Early awareness of opportunities
  • Control over information flows
  • Good for innovation and ideas

Tradeoff: Less protection, harder to mobilize support

Key Insight: The optimal network structure depends on what you‚Äôre trying to achieve.

Information access favors brokerage. Trust-dependent transactions favor closure.

Key Takeaways

1

Networks create value through two mechanisms

Closure enables trust; Brokerage provides information access.

2

Position matters more than connections

It‚Äôs not just how many ties you have, but where they connect you in the network.

3

Network analytics has diverse business applications

From fraud detection to organizational design to understanding competitive dynamics.

4

Context determines optimal structure

Innovation needs bridges. Trust-dependent transactions need closure.

Questions?

Discussion Prompt


Think about your own professional network. Are you more of a broker spanning different groups, or embedded in a closed cluster of close colleagues?
